paragraph.docTitle: An overview of acyclotides: Past, present and future

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Acyclotides
Chassatides
Cliotides
Hedyotides
Panitides
Violacin A
A B S T R A C T

Acyclotides are plant-based, acyclic miniproteins with cystine knot motif formed by three conserved disulfide linkages and lack head to tail ligation. Acyclotides may not necessarily be less stable, even though they lack cyclic backbone, as the conserved cystine knot feature provides the required stability. Violacin A was the first acyclotide, isolated from
Viola odorata
in 2006. Until now, acyclotides have been reported from five dicot families ( Violaceae , Rubiaceae , Cucurbitaceae , Solanaceae , Fabaceae ) and one monocot family ( Poaceae ). In Poaceae , only acyclotides have been found whereas in dicot families both cyclotides and acyclotides have been isolated. In last 15 years, several acyclotides with antimicrobial, cytotoxic and hemolytic bioactivities have been discovered. Thus, although many naturally expressed acyclotides do exhibit bioactivities, the linearization of the cyclic peptides may result in loss of bioactivities.

Although, bioactivities of acyclotides are comparable to their cyclic counterparts, the numbers of isolated acyclotides are still few. Further, those discovered, have the scope to be screened for agriculturally important activities (insecticidal, anti-helminthic, molluscicidal) and pharmaceutical properties (anticancer, anti-HIV, immuno-stimulant). The feasibility of application of acyclotides is because of their relatively less complex biological synthesis compared to cyclotides, as the cyclization step is not needed. This attribute facilitates the production of transgenic crops and/or its expression in heterologous organisms, lacking cyclization machinery. Keeping in view the bioactivities and the wide array of emerging potential applications of acyclotides, the present review discusses their distribution in plants, gene and protein structure, biosynthesis, bioactivities and mechanism of action. Further, their potential applications and future perspectives to exploit them in agriculture and pharmaceutical industries have been highlighted.

Cyclotides were known to exist in cyclic form only , till the discovery and isolation of the acyclic violacin A from
Viola odorata
(
Ireland et al., 2006b
) The naturally occurring acyclic forms are termed 'acyclotides' ( Poth et al., 2012 ), 'linear cyclotides' or 'uncyclotides' ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ), as they possess an overall conserved cystine knot structure of the cyclotides with the typical three conserved disulphide linkages, except that they lack end to end ligation. According to Poth et al. (2012) , the term 'acyclotide' is most appropriate as it is unambiguous (as per the nomenclature of organic compounds) and conveys only one meaning (i.e. not cyclic). Therefore, the term 'acyclotide' will be used for acyclic forms and 'cyclotide' will be used for cyclized forms, throughout the manuscript.

∗
Corresponding author.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Proportion of acyclotides and cyclotides in six angiosperm families.

subSection.paragraph: In the last 25 years, more than 400 cyclotides including acyclotides have been isolated from various plants (https://www.cybase.org.au; Mulvenna et al., 2006b ). Till now approximately 60 species from six families ( Violaceae , Rubiaceae , Solanaceae , Cucurbitaceae , Fabaceae , Poaceae ) have been identified for the presence of cyclotides and acyclotides. Compared to the total number of angiosperm species, the number of species from which cyclotides and acyclotides have been isolated is very low. Cyclotides and acyclotides have been isolated most abundantly from Violaceae (317), followed by Rubiaceae (85), Fabaceae (76), Solanaceae (12), Cucurbitaceae (11) and Poaceae (9) (https://www.cybase.org.au; Poth et al., 2011 , 2012 ; Du et al., 2019 ; Gerlach et al., 2013 ; Kaas and Craik, 2010 ; Niyomploy et al., 2018 ). Currently approximately 55 acyclotides have been identified across the six angiosperm families (data compiled by authors from Cybase - a database of cyclic proteins and research papers, Table 1 ). Along with the list of acyclotides, the plants from where they have been isolated, subfamily and bioactivities are presented in Table 1 . Of the 55 acyclotides, 24 are found as acyclic analogues of cyclotides, present along with their respective cyclotides in the plants and 31 exist only in acyclic forms without their cyclic counterparts ( Table 1 ).

The number of acyclotides in each family is 20 in Violaceae , 11 in Rubiaceae , 2 in Solanaceae , 9 in Fabaceae , 4 in Cucurbitaceae and 9 in Poaceae . Fig. 2 shows the proportion of acyclotides and cyclotides in the six angiosperm families. Acyclotides are found most abundantly in the Violaceae family and least in the Solanaceae family. The number of acyclotides in the dicot families is much less compared to cyclotides. However, in the Poaceae (monocot) family, only acyclotides have been reported ( Nguyen et al., 2013 ). Nine acyclotides were isolated from
Panicum laxum
of the Poaceae family, whose cyclized forms were not detected ( Nguyen et al., 2013 ).

Bioinformatics and expression analysis of genome/gene sequences of some economically important Poaceae members (
Zea mays , Oryza sativa , Triticum aestivum , Hordeum vulgare , Saccharum officinarum
) revealed that the putative cyclotide-like genes lack the crucial terminal residue (D/N) essential for cyclization, indicating that they probably code for acyclotides only ( Mulvenna et al., 2006a ). Gruber et al. (2008) proposed that genes coding acyclotides appeared earlier in the evolutionary timescale viz before the divergence of monocotyledonous and dicotyledonous plants. Subsequently, the monocots did not evolve further to include cyclization process of the acyclotides whereas dicotyledonous plants (the asterids and rosids) accomodated the mutation (i.e insertion of D/N) which plays a key role in cyclization. Also, the presence of acyclotides in both monocotyledonous and dicotyledonous plants and absence of cyclotides in monocots suggest their ancient origin before the divergence of angiosperms into the two taxonomical groups ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ). Further, since Poaceae (monocots) have acyclotides only and is agriculturally the most important family, their evolutionary study will have implications in the breeding program of important crop plants such as maize, rice, wheat, sugarcane, bamboo which are cultivated at a large scale worldwide. However, it is worthwhile to note that even though bioinformatics analysis suggests that the genomes of
Z. mays , O. sativa , T. aestivum , H. vulgare , S. officinarum
contain acyclotides-like gene sequences ( Mulvenna et al., 2006a ), no acyclotides have been isolated from these Poaceae members. Till date,
Panicum laxum
, is the only Poaceae member, where acyclotides have been reported. Hence, to be able to comment more emphatically on the distribution status of acyclotides in Poaceae and subsequently monocots, more members of Poaceae /monocots need to be screened for acyclotides and/or cyclotides.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Comparative trends in number of publications of acyclotides and cyclotides.

Fig. 3. Multiple Sequence Alignment of acyclotides. All acyclotides with D (Asp)/N(Asn) at C-terminal end are acyclic analogues of cyclotides, whereas those ending with stop codon (*) are genetically predetermined acyclotides.

subSection.paragraph:
There are two categories of genes that encode for cyclotides as well as acyclotides: i) genes dedicated to encode cyclotides or acyclotides (in Cucurbitaceae , Poaceae , Rubiaceae , Solanaceae and Violaceae members); ii) albumin 1gene (composed of albumin 1a and albumin 1b domains) where the albumin 1b-chain is replaced by a cyclotide or acyclotide domain as in Fabaceae ( Nguyen et al., 2011b ; Poth et al., 2011 ). The genes that encode acyclotides exclusively, have a stop codon that replaces the codon of D/N at the C-terminal end of the acyclotide domain (
Ireland et al., 2006b
; Nguyen et al., 2013 ). However, there are also naturally occurring acyclotides (acyclic analogues) that coexist with their respective cyclotides in the same plant such as kalata B9 and kalata B10 ( Plan et al., 2007 ). The genes encoding such acyclotides have codon for D/N instead of the stop codon, at the C-terminal. Figure. 3 shows the multiple sequence alignment of some acyclotides with stop codons and other acyclic analogues of cyclotides with D/N residue at the C-terminal.

Genes of acyclotides of all six families ( Violaceae , Rubiaceae , Fabaceae , Solanaceae , Cucurbitaceae , Poaceae ) show the common domains viz . ER (endoplasmic reticulum) signal domain and the acyclotide domain ( Fig. 4 ). The N-terminal propeptide (NTPP) domain is present in all six families except Fabaceae . An additional N-terminal repeat (NTR) domain is reported in some acyclotides of Rubiaceae and Violaceae families. Genes encoding acyclotides (acyclic hedyotides and chassatides) of Rubiaceae are with and without the NTR domain respectively ( Fig. 4 ). A CTR (C-terminal repeat) domain is also present in the acyclotide genes of the Violaceae and Fabaceae families (
Ireland et al., 2006b
; Nguyen et al., 2011b ). The gene of the acyclotide violacin A has two stop codons present on either side of the CTR domain (
Ireland et al., 2006b
). Acyclotide genes of Fabaceae also have an additional albumin gene 1, chain A (A1a) domain following the linker sequence ( Nguyen et al., 2011b ; Poth et al., 2011 ). Cucurbitaceae has the most distinct gene architecture ( Fig. 4 ) with a peculiar arrangement of multidomain cyclotide regions preceding the C-terminal propeptide (CTPP) domain, which is followed by an acyclotide domain ( Mylne et al., 2012 ).

In Violaceae , the cDNAs encoding acyclotides may also have one or more cyclotide domains, whereas in other families cDNAs with only one acyclotide domain have been reported (
Ireland et al., 2006a
). In Rubiaceae , cDNA clones of acyclotides (some acyclic hedyotides and chassatides) have premature stop codons (
Nguyen et al., 2011 a
, 2012). In
Hedyotis biflora
of Rubiaceae , the, full-length clone ( HBC2 ) of the acyclotide, hedyotide B2 has NTR domain between NTPP and main acyclotide domain similar to that of Violaceae and resembles the gene organization of HBC1 (the full-length clone of cyclotide, hedyotide B1). The cDNA clones of acyclic chassatides from Rubiaceae family are exceptions as they have shorter gene length than the other Rubiaceae acyclotides due to the absence of NTR domain and short NTPP domain ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ). Thus, the genes of acyclic chassatides ( Rubiaceae ) are more similar to the acyclotides of Solanaceae family as compared to acyclic hedyotides of Rubiaceae . Acyclic chassatides and hedyotide B2 ( Rubiaceae ) are the only acyclotide genes which have an intron present in the ER signal domain ( Fig. 4 ) ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ).

Acyclotides of Solanaceae have similar gene architecture as that of the cyclotides of this family, viz , comprising of an ER signal domain, a short NTPP region, one acyclotide domain, and a six-residue C-terminal tail sequence. The only difference is the absence of a CTR domain in the precursor, as a stop codon truncates the sequence immediately after the main acyclotide domain ( Poth et al., 2012 ). The acyclotides from the plant
Clitoria ternatea (Fabaceae)
have also been referred to as acyclic cliotides ( Nguyen et al., 2011b , 2016). The genes encoding these cliotides have similar structure but are different from all other plant families; with one ER signal domain followed by one main acyclic cliotide domain which has replaced Albumin 1b knottin domain ( Nguyen et al., 2011b ; Poth et al., 2011 ). Flanking the acyclic cliotide domain, is a linker region followed by an albumin 1a domain ( Fig. 4 ). There are no NTPP and NTR domains. Serra et al. (2016) reported cyclization-competent cyclotide precursor genes (cTc6, cTc7, cTc10, cTc19, cTerA) from
Clitoria ternatea
which encodes cliotides (cyclic forms) along with their acyclic analogues.

In Cucurbitaceae family, both acyclotides and cyclotides are encoded on the same transcript ( Fig. 4 ). Such genes with multiple domains are called TIP-TOP genes and were discovered in
Momordica cochinchinensis ( Mylne et al., 2012 )
. These genes have ER signal and NTPP domains followed by 2–5 mature cyclotide domains and a terminal acyclotide domain preceded by CTPP domain ( Mylne et al., 2012 ). Each cyclotide domain is preceded by NTR domain and followed by CTR domain ( Fig. 4 ). In Poaceae , till now only acyclotides have been isolated and identified from the plant
Panicum laxum
and based on the genus, are termed panitides ( Nguyen et al., 2013 ). Analysis of their gene architecture showed that they have an intronless ER signal domain, a NTPP region and a main panitide domain ending with a stop codon at C-terminal end ( Fig. 4 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Diversity in gene architecture of acyclotides from six angiosperm families ( Violaceae , Rubiaceae , Fabaceae , Poaceae , Solanaceae , Cucurbitaceae ). (ER- Endoplasmic Reticulum, NTPP- N terminal propeptide, NTR- N terminal repeat, CTPP- C terminal propeptide CTR- C terminal repeat, A1a- Albumin 1 domain -chain A).

subSection.paragraph: High structural stability and diverse bioactivities of acyclotides have paved the way for several potential applications ( Gerlach et al., 2010 ; Nguyen et al., 2013 , 2012 ). The application of acyclotides in agriculture encompasses the major crops of Poaceae family such as rice, wheat and maize, where only acyclotide genes have been reported to express. Panitides, the acyclotides from Poaceae family possess antimicrobial, hemolytic and cytotoxic properties ( Nguyen et al., 2013 ). The bioactivities of cyclotides and acyclotides depend on their ability for membrane interaction and disruption ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ), which might affect insecticidal/pesticidal activity also. The predominance of acyclotides in Poaceae and their molecular diversity provides an opportunity for creation of diverse insecticides, active against a broad range of insects and pests affecting important food crops like rice, wheat and maize. Therefore, as in case of cyclotides, acyclotides can also be assayed for insecticidal/pesticidal activity and can be utilized in crop protection and management through production of transgenics, expressing insecticidal acyclotides ( Jackson and Gilding, 2015 ). Sprays containing solutions of highly stable insecticidal and antimicrobial acyclotides can also be used as green pesticides and for preservation of edible items respectively. As cattle feed mainly on grasses, inclusion of Poaceae members with antimicrobial acyclotides in their diet can have a positive effect on the cattle health ( Nguyen et al., 2013 ). Acyclotides can also be exploited for use in pharmaceutical industries. The highly stable nature of acyclotides, makes them potential molecules for peptide-based drug designing and bioactive epitope grafting. Moreover their antimicrobial properties make them promising alternatives to antibiotic therapy ( Nguyen et al., 2012 ). The acyclotide, Psyle C shows cytotoxic activity against human lymphoma cell lines and chemo-sensitization ( Gerlach et al., 2010 ). Acyclotides with such properties could be used for creating anti-cancer drugs and peptide-based therapies.

Keeping in view the future prospects, the first noticeable fact is that, the total number of acyclotides isolated until now, is much less compared to cyclotides. Hence, to increase their numbers as well as diversity, more plants, particularly members of Poaceae which apparently have only acyclotides, can be screened for isolation of more acyclotides. A logical approach before proceeding for isolation would be genome mining/transcriptome analysis using appropriate bioinformatics tools to search for putative acyclotide genes in the available plant genome sequences. This would also require developing bioinformatics search tools for identification of acyclotide genes in plant genomes. Considering the antimicrobial, cytotoxic and hemolytic activities of some acyclotides, more numbers should be assayed to obtain acyclotides with increased potency. Further, other bioactivities such as insecticidal, pesticidal, molluscicidal, anticancer, immunomodulatory and other pharmaceutical activities need to be explored. Although some clues on mechanism of action of acyclotides is available, more investigation is required to establish exact mechanisms. This can facilitate screening and identifying potentially bioactive acyclotides by in silico methods like docking and simulations. Acyclotides do not need cyclization machinery, so their feasibility of transgenic expression for pesticidal activity in agriculturally important plants lacking cyclotides and cyclization machinery is an attractive proposition. Another focus of investigation would be their bulk production by heterologous expression in bacterial cells for agricultural (eg insecticidal sprays) and pharmaceutical (eg peptide-based drugs) purposes which is relatively simpler due to exclusion of cyclization step.

subSection.paragraph: Ramya Tammineni is a research student with a post graduate degree in plant sciences from University of Delhi , India . Her research involves analysis of putative gene and protein sequences of cyclotides in plant genomes using bioinformatic tools.

Pooja Gulati , Assistant Professor of Microbiology at Maharshi Dayanand University, Haryana , India is a PhD in Microbiology from University of Delhi , India . She has 12 years of research experience in molecular epidemiology and antibiotic resistance of microbes. She is currently investigating effect of some antimicrobial cyclotides on diverse strains of bacteria.

Sanjay Kumar, Assistant Professor of Microbiology at Maharshi Dayanand University, Haryana , India has a Doctorate degree in Biotechnology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, India . His area of focus is system engineering for host improvements using mobile genetic elements like plasmid modification, transposons and IS elements for recombinant protein expression. Currently he is working on heterologous expression of antimicrobial cyclotides.

Aparajita Mohanty, Assistant Professor of Botany at Gargi College, University of Delhi , India has done her Post doctoral from University of Madrid , Spain in plant population genetics of trees of European forests. Her research interests since last 10 years has also been in plant genome sequence analysis with a focus on biosynthetic pathways of bioactive compounds. Presently, she is working on genome wide search for linear cyclotides in members of Poaceae using bioinformatics tools.
